#Text=Vincenzo Calvesi
#Text=Silhouette of Vincenzo Calvesi
#Text=Vincenzo Calvesi ( fl. 1777 – 1811 ) was an Italian operatic tenor and impresario .
#Text=A skillful lyric tenor , he began his career performing in opera houses in Italy during the 1770s .
#Text=He was active in Dresden in 1782 to 1783 and then spent most of his time performing in Vienna from 1785 to 1794 .
#Text=He is best remembered today for creating the role of Ferrando in the world premiere of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart 's Così fan tutte in 1790 .
#Text=That same year the Viennese publication Grundsätze zur Theaterkritik described him as " one of the best tenors from Italy…with a voice naturally sweet , pleasant and sonorous . "

column1: #Text=He was later active in Rome as an impresario up until 1811 .
#Text=Life and career
#Text=Calvesi was born in Rome , the son of Bernhard Calvesi , a papal chamberlain . [ 1 ]
#Text=His date of birth , his musical education , and the details of his youth are now unknown .
#Text=The first definite account of the singer was in 1777 for a series of performances in operas in Rome .
#Text=He actively performed in comic operas in Italy up through 1782 .
#Text=From 1782 to 1783 he sang in Dresden at the newly opened Kurfürstliches Hoftheater .
#Text=In 1784 he appeared at La Scala in the Milan premiere of Domenico Cimarosa 's Chi dell'altrui si veste presto si spogli .
#Text=While performing in Italy he married the soprano Teresa Calvesi who specialized in comprimario and soubrette roles . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1785 Calvesi and his wife joined the roster of singers at the Burgtheater in Vienna .
#Text=Calvesi made his first appearance at that opera house as Sandrino in Giovanni Paisiello 's Il re Teodoro in 1785 .
#Text=In July of that year he created the role of Casimiro in the premiere of Stephen Storace 's Gli sposi malcontenti . [ 3 ]
#Text=On 8 January 1788 he performed the role of Atar in the premiere of Antonio Salieri 's Axur , re d'Ormus opposite his wife as Fiammetta .
#Text=Tesesa sang supporting roles in Vienna , often in productions with her husband , up through 1791 ; with Ippolito in Paisiello 's Fedra being her greatest success . [ 4 ]
#Text=She was then active in theatres in London and Italy while her husband remained in Austria .
#Text=Calvesi continued to perform at the Burgtheater until 1794 , with the exception of the majority of 1788 , when he was at the Teatro di San Carlo in Naples .
#Text=He sang in several more world premieres at the Burgtheater , most notably portraying the role of Ferrando in the premiere of Mozart 's Così fan tutte on 26 January 1790 .

#Text=Other roles he created in Vienna were Artemidoro in Salieri 's La grotta di Trofonio ( 12 October 1785 ) , Eufemio of Syracuse in Storace 's Gli equivoci ( 27 December 1786 ) , Prince Don Giovanni in Vicente Martín y Soler 's Una cosa rara ( 17 November 1786 ) , and Endimione in Soler 's L'arbore di Diana ( 1 October 1787 ) .
#Text=On 5 November 1785 he performed the part of the Count in the world premiere of Mozart 's quartet Dite almeno , in che mancai , K. 479 .
#Text=He also sang in the premiere of Mozart 's trio Mandina amabile , K. 480 on the following 21 November , which was written by Mozart for Francesco Bianchi 's La villanella rapita . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 1794 Calvesi retired from the stage and returned to his native Italy .
#Text=Somewhere around 1796 he began working in Rome as an impresario .
#Text=He was one of the city 's leading organizers of concerts and theatrical events up through 1811 .
#Text=After that his whereabouts and activities are unknown .
